newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela-Japan Venalum spat still unresolved.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela-Japan Venalum spat still unresolved.

text.p: The Venezuelan government is still negotiating with Japanese partners in aluminum smelter Venalum over what compensation should be given to the Japanese for giving up veto rights in the company, a top government official said Thursday.

"We are still discussing what will basically be a reasonable compensation for modifying the company's statutes," Antonio Azpurua, coordinator of joint ventures at state holding Corporacion Venezolana de Guayana (CVG), told Union Radio.
Venezuelan and Japanese officials announced in late September that a preliminary agreement had been reached to reduce the Japanese consortium's veto powers in Venalum.
But since then little progress had been made and government officials have suggested that they are not prepared to meet demands for $50 million in compensation.
The Venezuelan government hopes to privatize Venalum along with three other aluminum sector companies on Jan 31.

The Japanese consortium which holds a 20 percent stake in Venalum includes Showa Denko KK, Kobe Steel Ltd, Sumitomo Chemical Co Ltd, Mitsubishi Materials Corp, Mitsubishi Aluminum Co Ltd and Marubeni Corp.
